title: Driving Innovation with Open Data and Interoperability
segmentation: So first of all, it is a great honor and a privilege to be here amongst so many people doing work in teaching and developing and in taking the semantic web to the next generation.
So I'm not here to tell you what you already know about the semantic Web.
What I'm here to do is show you what people are doing with open data, linked data and the semantic Web in action.
So as Jim mentioned, one of my full time jobs is to be the evangelist for data.gov.
So as part of the government.

Organization within the USI work directly with the White House on opening up government data so that people can get better value delivered to citizens, and so it is less about a specific thing then about the idea behind it.
There are really just three questions to ask about open data.
The fur.
Is wire agencies sharing data?
Because if we don't have a feeder line in there, we don't get data out right?
So to be honest, some agencies are just doing it because they were told to do it right.
It's the government and there's a compliance issue.

So whether it's NASA where our fundamental act of formation, which was the space Act of 1958, requires us to share as wide as practical, the dissemination of information that we gather about our Earth and the heavens.
Whether it's that kind of compliance or audit compliance.
Or some other kind of reporting agencies are prompted to do that.

More Interestingly, though, we're really looking about the change and transformation within the government to telling citizens what the government is doing to engaging citizens with what the government could be doing.
That transformation of government is a big part.
The open data movement.
The second reason that we need to think about open data is why are countries sharing data?
So it's one thing for Department or City to put something out, but it's a separate thing for a nation to make a commitment, and we're seeing that happen all over the world.
So why are countries doing that?
Well, one is that they consider open data to drive innovation.
So by creating this infrastructure of linked data, this infrastructure of smart capability that they know things like the US Weather Service which drives.
A multi billion dollar industry and empowers it that things like that can come up for their organizations in their countries and they can kickstart innovation.

So wherever that innovation may lead us in the future, whether it's a small startup company now or whether it's all of us living together on another planet in the future, the innovation is where we're headed.
Now, why do people want data so people want data so that they can improve their lives?
I mean, that's kind of what drives us all right to be healthier.
To get better education for our kids ourselves, to be able to get better government services and capabilities.
So I paid the bribes.
An amazing sight that some of you might know about it.
So it's a site.
It's not a US specific site, but this is a great way for people to anonymously report when they've had to pay a bribe, or when they didn't have to pay a bribe.
A traditional place.

And this kind of open data that citizens are generating now not just coming out of governments are transforming governments and making it so that people have the power to change their governments and to change their behaviors.
Because releasing open data is not about the data itself, it's about empowering people to make better decisions and change their behavior in ways that will improve their lives.
So the story I'm going to tell you today is not so much about how great data.gov is because it is a work in progress, as all of those in the room.
And I see a few familiar faces who do open data work.
You know that this is something that we're always trying to improve, and the reason I was so delighted to be here today is because the semantic web and linked data or one of the areas that we have.
A huge need for improvement on the open data sites, but it's really also about helping people get the information they need to make better decisions.
So the first part of my story is about data.gov.
In this case, what we needed to do was look at the idea of creating a data ecosystem, because it's not about one aspect, it's not about just publishing data.
It's about getting people to use that data, and to do that, there's often intermediaries along the chain, right?
There's people who have to help have that conversation.
So on his first day in office, President Obama signed the Open Government Act, which required agencies to change the way that they were doing business.
To go from a need to know where only our friends and a few close colleagues get to know the information to a need to share.
So it was opening up and transforming the government's data and information systems.
In order to do that, we needed to gather more data, connect the community across the agencies and with the public, provide an infrastructure which didn't really exist between agencies.
At this time, every agency had to create their own infrastructure for data management, and generally that was on a per funded project basis.
So at NASA we had hundreds and hundreds of data sources.
Because you have hundreds and hundreds of historical projects, and each of those had a cost to it and infrastructure and an Accessibility issue where it was hard for people to be able to find.
All of the data about, say storms or hurricanes.

We also then needed to do something very different for the government which was work with professors, academics, students and developers in a way that would give them opportunities, provide funding opportunities, and help to kick the drive of innovation up from academia and out into the workplace and then back into the government to make that transformation happen.
But then we couldn't stop there, right?
It's an ecosystem.
So then we had to go back and gather more data.
So data.gov started with just 47 little datasets because it was an experiment, but that experiment has grown after three years to 400,000 datasets.
We get contributions from 170 two different agencies within the government.
My first started on data.gov.
I didn't realize we had 172 agencies in the government, but then we've got all of those people contributing and we expose the metrics on their contributions.
So in some ways what we do is we.
Kind of, you know, guilt them into out doing their other agency colleagues and competitors.

We also don't limit it to usdata, nor do we limit it to federal data, so we also grab information from the United Nations that we CD program and from the World Bank we have a few datasets from other countries as well.
And then we are also working on cities, States and counties.
It's a big change in policy for the government, will tell you more about that later and we also link to non government data.
So when it makes sense within one of our.
Topical communities like energy will link to utility data and other information.
So we try to make the data easy to find.
Now search is always the thing people hate most on any government website, so it's always an area where we're improving.
Again, I'm so anxious to hear about all the research and work that you guys are doing to to help us understand how we could do this better.
But we have, you know, traditional ways of looking through things.
We have very light taxonomy, but we're working towards ontology work with schema.org and some others so people can go in.
They can search, they can browse for data through a variety of categories.
And kind of zone in on the data that they want.
'cause with four 100,000 datasets it's a little hard to find the needle in the haystack.
Sometimes we have tag clouds.
You can find out what other people are looking for and what's popular, and so there's lots of ways to go in and find the data.
And then we also help you visualize it.
So if you're a developer, how many people in the room are developers?
OK, and you can raise your hand for multiple things here.
How many people teach?
OK, and how many people are students?
And how many people work in a business?
Alright.

So for some of you, the idea of visualizations is like Doug, I mean this is really easy to do, but when you think about the general citizen coming to data.gov, they are out and they want to see data they really don't want to see the spreadsheet of data they really don't.
They want to see that data in a way that's meaningful to them.
So part of what we do is we provide tools on the site that with one or two clicks can give them a visualization of the data that they're looking at.
And more Interestingly, what we find.
Is it's not visualization of AAD data set, which can be interesting, but the mashup of two datasets or three or four.
So when they start putting datasets together from different agencies across different topical areas, that's where real insights happen.
Our data journalists that work off data.gov data do this all the time, and it really provides an interesting insights, especially into government transparency and performance.
But all of these are things that can be created really easily on data Gov Interactive datasets mapping.
And all sorts of visualizations.
So the way that we power this is through a variety of advanced technologies.
Maybe I should say advancing technologies, because again, we're always in that situation where we're trying to move forward and always see the possibilities of improvement.
So we provide developers with tools and Rob Resources.
We have a developers community insight that's growing.
We release our code on open source through GitHub, so we have a community there, and we're building a community on drupal.org as part of our infrastructure is built on Drupal.
And we work with partnerships.
Jim mentioned the W 3C and I will in kind mention Jim in RPI has been working with us since the beginning and trying to look at the semantic web and linked data.
Jim is our semantic web lead on data Gov and we work closely with the WC both in the government interest Group, the Accessibility Group as well as the government linked data.
Our data is hosted in the cloud environment.
We have an open source platform and we're really building on the ontologies that others have been creating, either on schema.org.
I so AG you IEEE.
We have a lot of science data on data.gov, and so we tend to use ontologies that are already being expressed in those communities.
Like all of you, since I saw so many teacher hands raise up, we understand the importance of students in this process and the importance of teachers in this process.
So part of what we do is we highlight when people are doing really interesting things.
So we have a page called learn at data.gov that is highlighting work that you all are doing at universities across the country and around the world and teaching open data.
If your name isn't on our list, email me.
Tweet me.

Connect with me across any social media network and I will add your name and a link to your course syllabus or other course materials because I think it's really important for us as an academic community to also share teaching materials and the ways in which are trying to drive that learning with our students.
We also highlight different opportunities for students.
We have challenges and funding opportunities for students who might be doing something specific on open data that's worked through our sister project called challenge.gov.
And then we also work with the United Nations in looking at standards and data and information from the international community as well for students in learning.
So all of this helps to drive us to the threshold of great.
We've got.
All this data were starting to teach people about it, but what do we do with it?
And really, that's the second half of my story.
So the second half of the story is how do we develop that ecosystem?
And how do we build a new 21st century economy on open data?
So you've probably heard some of these stories before, but the fact is, I think it bears repeating clearly.
Two big changes happened with the release of Open Data as a service in the government over the last 10 or 15 years.

So one of these involved Noah, which is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and they gather weather data, and they used to charge people for this, and it was really hard to access and hard to understand.
But sometime ago Noah decided that you know what weather data isn't really something that we should be like holding and owning.
It's it's something everybody can benefit, so they provide it as a service.
Well, once it became a service, it moved from having sort of a monopoly lock on it to anybody being able to use weather data.

So whether it's weather.com or websites that use weather data, whether it's information that's helping us to understand on mobile apps or new companies that use weather data as part and parcel of the services and information that they're providing, so for example, when you all looked at booking a flight or train to come here today, probably you looked and saw the information about those flights, and part of that would have probably given you weather conditions at the destination as well.
So even sites like.
Kayak and others are trying to integrate weather services and open data services into adding more value for their customers.
The second thing that was an interesting sort of kickstart to some economic development was with the Air Force.
So the US Air Force had been using the Global Positioning satellite system for quite some time, and being able to track sort of their own logistics issues around the globe.
But at one point they sided with the service itself is not a national security issue.
I mean where are ships or we're not where planes are where soldiers are.
That information might be, but the service itself.
There's no real reason why we have to hold that.
In effect, there's a lot of reason why we should release that information so specifically around safety, so shipping, safety, Transportation Safety.
The more people knew about where other things were in position to them, the safer they'd be.
So they released GPS, had no concept, no idea of the generation of new economies around that, so all of us are carrying mobile devices.

Pretty much guarantee at a conference like this that are all enabled with tons of apps that are using GPS and think about if each of those developers had to pay for the service or had to try and create such a service.
I mean we would have very few capabilities that we.

All sort of live and die on today, so the idea that we can generate what is an over 100 billion dollar industry driven by these just these two open data services means that there is a huge market potential for other new open data.

I was recently at the Iscove conference talking and the thing that came up there over and over again was part of the new research needed is on sort of making it very clear the economic value around open data.
So part of the way that we define and arrived at economic value on data.gov is to look at the building of communities.

So this was something that I brought over with the work I had done from NASA where I built communities throughout the Department of Defense and NASA and with the public using a variety of technologies.
Everything from gaming to social media to traditional web services and collaborative systems, and what and what I realized was that data.gov was missing this idea of communities of.
People coming together around a specific topical area that was of interest because the more data grew, the more difficult it was for people to kind of find their way through it.
I mean, we had search but we didn't really have the ability for people to collaborate around the data.
So we have been developing these communities for the last year.
We have another 20 four communities in development, my number doubled yesterday was very productive day in Washington.
So you can see the variety here from health to Lotta Energy to oceans.
All the way down to cities.
One of our more interesting communities is ethics.

Ethics is treated a little bit differently than the other communities and that it brings together a small but powerful group of data sets in an interactive way so you can search for your senators name.
You can find all of the campaign financing that went to her or him.
You can find all of the bills that they voted on, and if they're in the White House, you can find the visitor logs well.
Depending on what you're analyzing.
Looking at that could provide a lot of insight to how that campaign has been driven.
So our ethics site is a particularly popular site.
But what we really realized is that open data is an ecosystem we have to get all of these players together.
We do that through these communities, so these are public facing spaces that bring the data, Information Services and players altogether.
And it's not just an on line space, because that's one way to collaborate and people do.
But what we find really drives behavior and change in industry is that interaction.
Now we're all budget constrained and it's difficult to get everybody together.
And So what we do is we have a lot of virtual meetings augmented by face to face opportunities.
So each of our communities meets either every week or every other week virtually, and those groups are sometimes just a small set of folks, but generally at least once a month.
That includes, it's open to the community, which means it's open to anybody in the public.

So our energy meeting has over 100 participants, with of those hundred participants, maybe a dozen are from the government, most are from utilities, new startups, researchers, students, developers, University energy clubs, so.
These communities are really meant to be public facing and open.
Everything is open to the public.
Everything we do on data transparent.
So as we start these communities, when I first talk to somebody who's interested in the new community.

And I asked them this series of questions which helps me to understand it helps them to understand what the vision is that's going to draw people in an what it is that's going to create this ecosystem for them.
So first of all, we don't talk about this site.
Everybody wants to see what's going to be on the site first.
I'm like the site is the least important part of what we're doing.
The important part is how is this going to change and improve the lives of American citizens?
How are we going to make sure that that's led?
Who's going to participate?
What's the vision for what we're going to be like?
A year from now, what are people going to be coming to the site to do to change to, to ask for more of or less of?
Because part of what we do is we have.
Again, it's a.
It's an open government initiative and as part of that what we do is transparent when somebody requests a new data set and what our responses to that.
So anytime somebody wants data needs data, they contact data.gov, which there's only five of us on data.gov.
So all the content comes to me so it all comes into my inbox.
Or through my social media networks and as a result, then I'm always on top of trying to make sure that people are getting those responses and it's very public.
Whether or not I am responding, so it's a great encouragement to be transparent.
So let me give you a little taste of how this works in our energy community.
So our energy community, which can be found at.
Bizarrelyenergy.data.gov like healthhealthdata.gov and ocean.data.gov Energy is community that came out of a presidential requirement.
So President Obama specifically asked that we develop six of our data.gov communities around issues of national importance.
Things like public safety and education and health and energy.
So our energy community is one that is very active.
We meet every week with the group of people who are trying to develop.
And push out new data and then we have every monthly monthly meetings with over 100 people from the from the public and anybody is welcome to join those at anytime.
We use that community to help change the way in which we want to offer services from the government and the way in which we want to drive innovation in the energy industry.
So each of our communities has a slightly different focus.

Oceans is all about helping coastal and marine spatial planners, so that means if you wanna fishery or your city planner along one of the Great Lakes, then that's the community that's going to give you a lot of interesting information.
But on energy, it's really about driving innovation.
So we put out a variety of challenges on things like challenge.gov that helped to drive forward where we're going with with energy consumption, energy efficiency, energy research across the nation.
And out of those we get tons of new ideas and applications and then we get others that are just contributed by people and citizens have been using open data to create new capabilities.
So this is an example of one of them.

It's called the Sustainable Facilities tool and this is great because if you're thinking of remodeling your house, but you're sort of green minded, you don't really know what kind of flooring, for example to put in or what kind of paint to use or how to do that remodeling in a way that's going to have a green choice.
Well, this lets you walk through really simply.
I want to put in hardwood flooring.
Oh well, so maybe a rare wood that's beautiful is not necessarily my best choice, but I can choose something that's just as pretty, but is a much greener solution.
It helps guide you through all of the trade offs for that, so each of these apps can be downloaded directly from the Android Marketplace or the iTunes store, depending on kind of which platform.
If their mobile app or take you directly to the site, so we try not to.
We don't limit this to government developed applications.
We really are.
Focused on Citizen developed applications.
So one of the ways that we have changed the industry is that we created this initiative called the Green button.
Buttons, buttons.

We originally had a Blue button initiative which was part of our healthcare opportunity which looked at creating a way for veterans who are coming out of the service to be able to with a click, download all of the historical health information, put it on a drive and take it to the doctor.

Because it turned out, it was very hard to get those records out so that when a person came out of the service they sort of start all over and the doctor didn't know all the things that it happened to them all the injuries.

Our issues that they had had while they were in the service, so that was a really successful initiatives been very popular, but we have a green button which works with utility companies across the country.
So part of what we wanted to do was change the way that people looked at energy efficiency in their homes.
So the first thing we did was talk from the White House, talk to a lot of different people and said if we want to change it so that Americans are more fuel efficient, the big issue is.
Home use and we don't have that data right?
I mean you buy your home energy from your local utility company or some of you might have you know solar panels or other other generated information.
But we don't.
We don't have that.
So we created this initiative called the Green button which really worked with utility companies around the country starting in California, where it's now been fully implemented.
But moving across the country.
So these utility companies agreed that they would provide in the same format, downloadable with just the little click of a button there, so I'm.
I live in Los Angeles myself, so I can go to my Southern California Edison site, click the button, download all my historical data.
Maybe that's useful to me, but it's more useful to me.
And most people that there are a ton of new apps or 45 apps that have been developed around this.
Everything from gamification so I can compete with my friends to see who stated the most energy this month.
Or I can if I'm on a smart grid home I can actually control my thermostat from my smart phone to be able remotely to be able to go.
Oh my gosh, I forgot to turn my air conditioning down or my heater down when I left the house this morning.
So all of these help me make better decisions and better control my costs.
This whole idea of open data.
The government at the US is really driven by a variety of activities.
One is the new US digital strategy.
So we four years ago when President Obama came into office, he founded 2 new offices.
One was the US chief information officer and the other was the US Chief Technology officer.
So those current people are Steven Vanroekel who was originally at Microsoft and Todd Park, who is health?
Force of nature.

If you've ever met Todd, you know what I'm talking about, and both of them are really driving aggressively forward in the ability for the government to help spur economic innovation and to release more data.

So Steve's recent US digital strategy was really focused on making sure that we as a government take it as the standard minimal capability that all possible data will be released in usable formats, and that we unlock the power of that data.
To improve the quality of life for our American citizens so you can find this digital strategy.
Of course you know it has to have a mobile application to as well as well as the strategy itself.
And then the second driving document for us is the US Open Government action plan.

So this is part of the US participation in the Open Government Partnership, which is a consortium of about 50 different nations around the world who have made formal commitments to have more open and transparent governments.
So a year ago, President Obama had gotten before the UN General Assembly and stated 26 actions that would occur over the next year.
Two of those involved data Gov One, was contributing data.gov as the open source.
Platform and the second was to do that in partnership with the Government of India and the second one was to double down on the number of communities that we had on data.gov.
Specifically focused around some areas of national interest.
A year later, just this last September when he got back there, we were able to let him report that we had completed both of these, so I told you a little bit about our community.
But let me tell you what we've done with the open government platform.
So it's been a long and winding Rd to the three years to get to where we are today.

To be able to take go from 47 datasets to 400,000 to go from 3 agencies to 172 and to be able to have the reach and connection of developers to be able to see hundreds and hundreds of applications and capabilities and thousands of visualizations show up on the use of government data.

The infrastructure of it has taken an inordinate amount of time, not not an inappropriate amount of time, but given all of the things that any nation or city organization has to do in thinking about the release of data, the infrastructure is really the least.
Important part for them to focus on right, they need to focus on the policy's how they're going to get the data out.
What are they going to release?
How are they going to connect with developers and data journalists and others?
How are they going to drive learning in their universities so that they create a whole new generation of folks, particularly in the developing world who are poised to make use of that open data?
Those are the things they should be thinking about, not necessarily.
You know, should they be using this product or that product?
So we partnered with the Government of India.

And it's actually been a really great project over the last year to take the best that they had in their data.gov dot in planning and what we had on data WS as well as looking at other things like see Canon and other activities going around the world.
And we've put that together into an open source capabilities.
So we've delivered it on GitHub.
We just had our second code update last Friday and will have another one coming up next month.
And what this does is it provides a way for anybody to download.
And install the open government platform.
So this includes the data management system, customer relationship management system, the website itself in our communities, and from that it's a lot easier for them to get started.
We're currently working with four governments, Rwanda, Ghana, Canada and Mexico as they are implementing this in their organizations.

So the other thing we're trying to do is really focus on data that is not at the federal level and from a policy perspective this was like 2 years of policy in two days of technology to make this happen.

But we've released our new cities, data.gov and later you'll hear you'll see our States and counties.data.gov coming up, but we have about a dozen cities available and you can search through those and you can see the distinction when you when you look at it between.
Federal data and then city data and what's interesting is when you search for things like like hospitals or parking or energy across each of those.
All of those datasets that you then get the aggregation.
So as Jim mentioned, I I go to a lot of hackathons, alot of things.
I think last year is at 25 hackathons.
Most of those seem to be an energy and transportation.

So when I would go there I would talk to developers and part of what I would do is say tell me the data you need and if we don't have it, let me let me get it pushed out this weekend and see if we can't publish it right away.
So they would say, OK, well, we're here in Boston and we want data about, you know, transportation great.
I have data about Boston Transportation because it's the Federal Highway transportation system, right?
Well, yeah, but I need local roads.
I need city roads.
Any County roads.
I need Interstate highways.

Oh wow, I don't know if Austin has an open data, so I don't know if your County has so this frustration of developers in this waste of time of them trying to find the data was something that helped to drive the idea of for goodness sakes.
Why don't we just make it all accessible to one group of people?
Through one interface.
So we're working with City, County and state CIOs, data officers and mayors and governors all over the country.
And you can see we've got all of these different states that have open data sites as well as a large number of cities.
And then we are so our first first state was the state of Hawaii.
I have to say that because they were our brave first first participants on the state site and then we have cities from all over and we are trying to make it really easy for cities.
So that by the end of December will have sort of the four basic ways that you can connect your data and to data.gov.
Again, we're not hosting it for them.
What we do is we focus on making it better, easier to access their data.
So today what we've got is a bit of a system that's been home grown over the years that has data set management, search on Jim's been a big part of Japan is big part of that.
With this group at RPI, we have 6.7 billion triples, and we both have the keyword search as well as faceted search.
There's a lot of geospatial.
90% of the data we have on data.gov has some kind of Geo tag on it, so even if it's data that we don't think of is like it's not a map, sort of.
Formal geospatial data like from a satellite at NASA.

Still even things like a hospital data has a Geo location, so 90% of our data has some kind of Geo tag, which means that visualizations, mapping and geospatial data standards are really important to us.
And then we're working now.

We've got vocab data.gov, so this is connecting with schema.org and some of the link to work coming out of George Thomas and the group at Health and Human Services and the government linked Data Group at the W 3C.
So as we implement that digital strategy as we move forward, we're also introducing the idea of having this as an open source capability across the world that anybody can be able to use.

It makes a lot easier for us to integrate data on international issues like climate change, education and human rights, and also to have an API key registry so that we don't have to actually like download the data and massage it.
But we just have a list of web services APIs that allow people to connect to that data.
Enhancing the search in the vocabulary and really working towards more standards driven approaches.
So we've currently been using Dublin Core for example as our metadata standard, but we're migrating to the European Union's ADMS, which would make it easier for interoperability across that.
So we do this with a lot of different partnerships.
So one of the partners that we have is is working with these associations like IEEE and age you and ISO and schema.org as well as crowd sourcing some of our folksonomies.

If I can use an old term, but really letting people tell us what the relationship is amongst the data and then Jim and his great team at RPI is really part of our group for helping us drive forward some of the work in way that we look at both linked data and the semantic web.
We work closely with the W3C.
And Sandro Hawke, I can see from who's our facilitator on the Government Interest Group is with the W3C and we have a lot of connections and insights that come out of that.

So it's very interesting we just finished up a group of meetings over the last three months with so I could share it with Thomas Janowsky who is in China, which makes it so that we have meetings at different time zones.
So it's very convenient for people around the world we just finished up a series of three months of discussions on social media any.
In governments and the use of that.
And it was very insightful to hear the different approaches that Russia and China and Finland in New Zealand in the US I'll take.

Not that one's good or bad, but it's interesting to see these different opportunities so that when somebody from Afghanistan is looking at whether or not they want to have social media as a capability of the government, they can compare it to other governments that are more familiar and similar to their own.
We work very closely with the Government of India and then a hats off to seek and developers in Rufus is public group, Rufus is Rufus Pollock's group.
At the Open Knowledge Foundation in the UK who are part and parcel of our new delivery of the Open Government platform.
So just a quick nod to linked data.
We're on the journey.
We're not at 5 stars.
But we understand the importance to get there, so I have an attitude that has driven part of part of this being a journey.
Which is it is better to have a PDF of data than not to have any data at all.

So you have to remember that part of that ecosystem is getting the agencies to share, and sometimes that first step is just getting them to share anything before I have to say, yeah, but I needed an XML when they haven't got a clue what I'm talking about.
So as part of a GPO will actually have some conversion tools that will help take you know things that are in CSV and move them into more interesting formats.
But on data.gov we have things on kind of this whole spectrum, so some things are in five stars.
Some things are in one star.
And my point is, is once you can get it in one start, you can start moving it forward.
So.
One thing we know, but one thing we're absolutely certain of, is that change is happening.
So we've talked a little bit about the story of how we got here with data.gov in the US government, but really, that is the least interesting part of the story today.
The most interesting part of the story today is what people are doing with this.
